snippet: The increase, which follows more than two decades of slow growth in college completion, appears to be driven by the recent recession and the creation of new types of jobs.
abstract: Federal data shows that number of Americans graduating from college has surged; 33.5 percent of Americans ages 25 to 29 had at least bachelor's degrees in 2012, compared with 24.7 percent in 1995; increase follows more than two decades of slow growth in college completion, apparently driven by recession and creation of new types of jobs.
lead_paragraph: The increase, which follows more than two decades of slow growth in college completion, appears to be driven by the recent recession and the creation of new types of jobs.

headline.main:
Data Reveal a
Rise in College
Degrees Among
Americans
headline.print_headline: A Sharp Rise In Americans With Degrees
